working_definition: Developmental Delay refers to children aged 3 through 9 who are experiencing delays in one or more of the following areas: physical development, cognitive development, communication, social or emotional development, or adaptive development. The delay must adversely affect the child's educational performance.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Global Developmental Delay
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: Significant delay in two or more developmental domains including motor, speech/language, cognitive, and social skills.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Motor Delay
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: Delay in developing gross or fine motor skills, such as walking, balance, or hand coordination.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Speech and Language Delay
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: Delay in receptive and/or expressive communication skills.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Cognitive Delay
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: Delay in thinking skills, problem-solving, and learning new tasks.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Social-Emotional Delay
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: Delay in developing age-appropriate emotional responses or interactions with others.

common_presentations: Delayed speech or difficulty expressing needs
Trouble understanding instructions or new concepts
Struggles with fine or gross motor tasks
Limited attention span or difficulty staying on task
Challenges in peer interactions or turn-taking
Difficulty with transitions or changes in routine
Immature emotional responses or frustration tolerance
Inconsistent self-care or daily living skills
Needs repeated practice to retain new skills

accommodations_modifications.name: Use of visual supports and picture cues
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Helps students follow routines and understand expectations
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Trouble understanding instructions or new concepts
accommodations_modifications.example: Student uses a visual schedule with icons for daily activities

accommodations_modifications.name: Speech and language support services
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Delayed speech or difficulty expressing needs
accommodations_modifications.example: Student receives 30 minutes/week with the speech-language pathologist

accommodations_modifications.name: Use of manipulatives and hands-on materials
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Supports concept development through tactile learning
accommodations_modifications.example: Student uses counting blocks to learn addition

accommodations_modifications.name: Frequent breaks and movement opportunities
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Limited attention span or difficulty staying on task
accommodations_modifications.example: Student gets a 2-minute movement break every 15 minutes

accommodations_modifications.name: Social skills instruction and modeling
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Builds turn-taking and peer interaction skills
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Challenges in peer interactions or turn-taking
accommodations_modifications.example: Student participates in weekly peer play groups led by a counselor

accommodations_modifications.name: Visual and verbal countdowns for transitions
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Prepares students for changes in activities
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Difficulty with transitions or changes in routine
accommodations_modifications.example: Teacher gives a 5-minute and 1-minute warning before cleanup

accommodations_modifications.name: Explicit instruction in emotional regulation
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Teaches appropriate emotional responses and coping skills
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Immature emotional responses or frustration tolerance
accommodations_modifications.example: Student uses a feelings chart to label emotions during circle time

accommodations_modifications.name: Task checklists with visuals
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Inconsistent self-care or daily living skills
accommodations_modifications.example: Student follows a hand-washing checklist with pictures

accommodations_modifications.name: Repetition and re-teaching of new material
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Needs repeated practice to retain new skills
accommodations_modifications.example: Student practices letter sounds daily with flashcards

accommodations_modifications.name: Occupational therapy services
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Improves fine motor skills and coordination
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Struggles with fine or gross motor tasks
accommodations_modifications.example: Student attends OT sessions to develop pencil grip and cutting skills
